title: Negotiating Difference in the City of Tomorrow
author: Dash N' Dem
Irina Shapiro
body:
A site specific mass recitation conceived during the Open Set Summer School in the Bijlmer, Amsterdam Zuidoost. Collectively written and performed by Rapper Mitchell ‘Mizztamizzo’, design action group Dash N’ Dem and workshop participants, Petra Hegenbart, Guga D’orea, Kenneth Aidoo, Ling Liu, Yong Hyun Lee, Nataly Kozhukhovskaya, Clemmy Tjin, Aissa Kraaijenbrink.
Caricatures or stereotypes representing different concepts, groups of people and positions from Bijlmer’s history, were selected to engage in debate and negotiate their differences. 
 
Characters
* * *
Architect’s Vision | The paternalistic Modernist plan  
The Jungle | A force of nature, unregulated and unknown
Tradition | Fear of immigrants who could change the local culture
Change | The driver of human progress and diversity
Open Window | The Dutch custom of leaving the curtains open
Venserpolder resident | Perplexed second-generation Surinamese resident
Low-rise House | Built in place of the demolished high-rises as part of the renewal 
The Displaced | Man forced to leave his flat, who can’t afford to stay in Bijlmer
The Bird | Nature’s response to human folly 
The Tourist | Searching for remnants of the modernist dream
* * *
*Text in BOLD should be chanted by the chorus.  

Scene I ~ The Plan Was Good
Architect’s Vision and The Jungle
Architect’s Vision:  I had a plan AND THE PLAN WAS GOOD. 
I planned a good neighborhood.
The Jungle: Did you plan a place for me, where I should I be?
Architect’s Vision: It was all for you.
The Jungle: What have you done? What have you planned? 
It was not for me, it was for you. 
Where should I go, WHERE SHOULD I GROW?
Architect’s Vision: I had a plan AND THE PLAN WAS GOOD. 
Just not for these people in this neighborhood. 
You took the place and it grew like a jungle. 
This was not the plan and we just took a gamble.
The Jungle: It was not for me, it was for you. 
Where should I go, WHERE SHOULD I GROW?
I like to go with the flow, grow around your squares but who cares?
Architect’s Vision: Care was all we did. Nothing asked in return and look what you did.
The Jungle: Finding my own way between your patterns.
Architect’s Vision: Our patterns gave you support.
The Jungle: And create obstacles to stumble over but never mind, 
I will get up and go and find my flow. 
Architect’s Vision:  A river without a bed, will flow astray. 
Our structures will keep you at bay.
The Jungle: Where should I go, WHERE SHOULD I GROW? Where will I flow? 
Look around, get out of your box, the sun is shining, we are far from whining. Not complaining just designing. 
Architect’s Vision: I had a plan AND THE PLAN WAS GOOD. 
The Jungle: Just not for this type of neighborhood, get out of the box, the sun is shining, let’s fill these squares and stop this whining.
Architect’s Vision: AND THE PLAN WAS GOOD. 
 
* * *
 

Scene II ~ Not from Here
Tradition and Change
* Change can be translated in any language and it is suggested that the chorus repeats the lines marked with a * , in as many different languages as the group speaks. 
 
Change: Do you speak English? *
Tradition: Oh! He’s not from here! HE’S NOT FROM HERE! 
You’re not from here. Where are you from?
Change: I am not from here but I am here to stay. 
I bring good things in many ways.
Tradition: He’s not from here. HE’S NOT FROM HERE!
He’ll change our ways. This is not what we want. 
The good must stay. What brought you here?
Change: I am bringing the new, I must say. 
But I never thought it would be this way.
Tradition: What do you want?
Change: I want to change. HE WANTS HIS CHANGE! *
Tradition: I don’t want to change. We have it good, 
We have our ways. And this is what stays. 
What do you want?
Change: I want my change. HE WANTS HIS CHANGE! *
Tradition: What do you have to give?
Change: All I got is an open heart, a will to give and a place to start. 
I don’t choose between black and white. 
Chorus:  YOU CHOOSE GREY! *
Tradition:  But we don’t mix and we have the say.
Change: Maybe someday, MAYBE SOME DAY * 
you will embrace our ways, as we embrace your ways.
 
* * *

Scene III ~ The Dutch Way 
Open Window and Venserpolder resident
Venserpolder resident: Why can I see into your home?
Open Window: You can take a look — there is nothing to hide
Chorus:  THIS IS THE DUTCH WAY!
Venserpolder resident: Aren’t you scared robbers come inside?
Open Window: We have no fear. We welcome you. 
We show the inside to the outsiders too.
Venserpolder resident: What makes you think I want to look through you and see the owners as they read their books?
Open Window: I’m here to frame our lives how beautiful and open to everyone outside. 
Chorus:  THIS IS THE DUTCH WAY!
Venserpolder resident:  In our community there’s a lot of pride, curtains are for privacy and not to hide. 
Open Window: Closed windows only separates people from being together. 
Venserpolder resident: But your window is never open no matter the weather. 
We can all be outside and share together. 
Open Window: People in the neighborhood never feel alone, when we can all see each other. 
Chorus:  THIS IS THE DUTCH WAY!
Venserpolder resident: Then I won’t even bother. 
Chorus:  THIS IS THE DUTCH WAY!
 
* * *

Scene IV ~ Not Built for You
Low-rise House and The Displaced
The Displaced:  Why am I being forced to go?
Low-rise House:  Because your income IS TO LOW!
The Displaced: What am I supposed to do? 
Low-rise House: I was not built for you? 
Chorus: THEN WHO?
Low-rise House: The ones who can enjoy my lush green grass, are the more affluent middle class. 
The Displaced: I was part of this community, I DESERVE THE OPPORTUNITY! 
The Displaced: I deserve respect, I HAVE BEEN TREATED WITH NEGLECT!
Low-rise House: I do appreciate your concern, call the housing corporations complaints line and wait for your turn. 
 
* * *
 
Scene V ~ No Utopia  
The Bird and The Tourist
 
The Bird:  Hello stranger I am a bird sitting on the wall. What on earth are you looking for?
The Tourist: I am looking for UTOPIA! I have come to experience the Modernist dream. 
l am looking for the buildings with the clean lines and uniform structures.  
Chorus:  UTOPIA! 
The Bird: What else are you looking for?
The Tourist: I am looking for the perfect balance of living around nature. 
Chorus:  UTOPIA!  
The Bird: What else are you looking for?
The Tourist: Happy people living in harmony. 
Chorus:  UTOPIA!  
The Bird: What else are you looking for?
Chorus:  UTOPIA!  
The Bird: There is no utopia. NO UTOPIA!
The Tourist: What about the modernist dream?
Chorus:  UTOPIA!  
The Bird: The modernist dream no longer exists, 
Chorus:  Utopia!  (quieter)
The Bird: The modernist high rise have been torn down
Chorus:  Utopia (even quieter)   
The Tourist: What about the perfect balance of living around nature?
Chorus:  UTOPIA!  
The Bird: The perfect balance of living around nature no longer exists. 
Chorus:  Utopia! (quieter)
The Bird:  But you can see 1000 pieces of trash from 1000 vibrant cultures.
Chorus:  Utopia  (even quieter)     
The Tourist: What about people living in harmony?
Chorus:  UTOPIA!  
The Bird:  People no longer live in harmony, but you can see rich home buyers, threatening your neighbors to move away.
Chorus:  Utopia!  
The Bird: There is no utopia.
Chorus: There is no utopia. 
The Tourist: There is no utopia.
Chorus:  There is no utopia.
 
* * *

title: Mutations & Explosions
author: María Muñiz
body:
Mutations & Explosions is an ongoing research project by María Muñiz. It is not a conclusion, but rather an experimental prototype resulting from an exploration of the Netherlands Institute for Sound and Vision. In her first contact with an archive, Muñiz was fascinated by the place of archivism within the context of identity, heritage, and culture. Instead of navigating the audiovisual content, she decided to work with the archive as an entity, as a container of data, to allow for its rethinking free from the biases of social, cultural, and political perspectives.
The project aims to shape the birth and evolution of n(e)o-archives, to initiate a conversation about the value of information, its format, and the methods of its storage, and to open questions on a speculative vision of the future of archiving. On the one hand, the project confronts the ways in which information is affected by the changes we make to the format of the material to be archived – scanning film movies or printing digital images, for example – and the ways in which the material is required to mutate according to different contemporary needs, such as technology. From this scenario, Muñiz has developed a non-sense process for reformatting images in order to emphasize the non-reversible conversion of information. On the other hand, she presents technology as the answer to (or perhaps as a new conflict within) reflections regarding engagements with the archives of society: breaking the archive’s passive role, or establishing a certain responsibility that gives society agency over their own cultural heritage.
As a result, the installation presents a video mutation booth (a screen with a hacked scanning system) linked to an online network based on the blockchain notions of decentralised and public databases. Each film is visually encrypted (mutated) by the device, creating a new, portable, and unique version of itself. A single frame containing the information of the complete clip is subsequently shared in this network. Each time a new user requests to join the network, the system scans any film – creating a closed loop that links the physical and virtual universes. The entire archive will be encrypted and shared (avoiding Copyright issues) through a new community who will guard it.
Mutations & Explosions represents a new working paradigm for Muñiz, a self-hacking process in which she herself mutated and exploded as a designer. She aimed to develop a project from a very personal perspective, centred in her own background in industrial and graphic design and in digital culture. However, she breaks with all of her preconceived ideas and proposes a new scenario for creation, following her instincts in order to allow the mind to make impossible connections, and conducting experiments to dismantle the answers. A disruptive process of failures, questions, and confusion that ultimately leads to illumination.

title: Single Images (Alleenstaande beelden)
author: Mariska van Zutven
body:
The Dutch Centre of Statistics claims that by 2060 40% of the Dutch population will live in a one-person household. Mariska van Zutven photographs and writes about singles: individuals who are not in a partner-relationship and live in one-person households. During Open Set Lab Mariska researched how the increasing number of singles appear in the Archive of the Netherlands Institute for Sound and Image.
Mariska often works with big collections of images. Big collections connect single images to their context and give her the opportunity to reflect on the complete collection as well as on every single image. One of the first films concerning singles she found in the archive was a promotion broadcast in 1937 of a home for a single intellectual man in Groesbeek. The home was payed for and set up by the community to keep the educated man from declining in society. Taking care of this man was seen as an act of charity.
During the ’60s and ’70s, the aired material changes. Items and programs show the emancipation of women, discussions about taxes for singles and imagery of working women in industry. Mariska van Zutven also found several studio interviews from the ’80s as well as conversations with singles at their homes during the ’90s and after the year 2000.
The questions posed to singles change over time. In early TV programs questions about housing conditions and freetime activities were frequently asked. Slowly the questions change, asking the singles why they are not in a partner-relationship, or how they are searching for a new partner.
Experts on relationships, lonelyness, housing and dating become more frequently introduced on television.
Help and therapy are available and broadcast. While interviewing singles, more lively documentairy images of their lifestyles appear on TV, showing the public how singles live their lives and find a new partner. Technology is entering the lives of singles and entering the TV screen during the interviews.
While working in the digital archive, Mariska van Zutven was, in a way, searching the database of the institute in the same manner in which singles search for partners on dating sites;, sometimes searching the database using exact search words, sometimes scanning intuitively, looking for a lucky match and sometimes even mindlessly clicking and discovering new things in the database. How do we look for the things we need? What do we encounter on the way, when searching? Do we create stories on our journey? Connect similarities and patterns we were previously unaware of? And what defines a good search? Reflecting on her search strategy became an important part of her project Single Images.
For her presentation during the Fluid Memory Conference, at Sound and Vision Mariska used screenshots of the ‘keyframes’ used to collect the available material on singles. The keyframes are produced by Immix, the digital search interface of the Archive. The keyframes in the archive are still images of every first frame of the next shot, after the camera has moved. The aired program can be viewed in the database through the keyframes, showing a visitor the narrative through a collection of film stills. In her project Single Images Mariska created a new archive of keyframes on singles

title: Leaders Fail
author: Stefan Christian
body:
Archives often seem a bit arcane and boring, but they are much more than just a collection of dusty files. They preserve and sustain narratives about our cultural heritage, give us insights into our past, and they inspire us when we think about our future. They can motivate us to create our own archives, and then the verb archive becomes an artistic, sociological or activist strategy to bring other narratives to life.
Rather by accident, while talking to Arne Hendriks, one of the mentoring artists during the Open Set programme, I remembered an old post in the NOS Journal that I had found in the archive. In this post, a news presenter made a mistake and started to laugh. Arne Hendriks told me that sometimes you just have to try things out, just because it’s fun or interesting in that moment. So I started collecting mishaps, specifically focusing on the unexpected events that happen to politicians on television.
Public appearances by politicians are often reminiscent of static staging in an opera house. They look like puppets with rehearsed movements and phrases. Most perform without mistakes. But sometimes, however, politicians are surprised by environmental influences or minor inattentions. In seconds the rehearsed performance collapses. That’s why these mishaps are so interesting. They show an unexpected dramatic twist in a stereotypical event that surprises us and makes us laugh. At the same time, these slip ups  are proof that politicians are people who, despite practice and routine, make mistakes.

This search turned out to be extremely cumbersome, since TV mishaps are not explicitly identified in the register of the Sound & Vision archive. I continued my search in video portals that ranked videos by popularity. Mishaps by well-known politicians were listed pretty high in the search results. For instance, some politicians have only one video with a public appearance – the one with the mishap. Due to the same quest for popularity, a certain mishap story can also be found in newspaper articles. This material brought me to new political figures, events, and dramas. While the collection became richer, I did not have another choice but to create my own small archive of politicians’ TV slip ups.

title: Area +31
author: Ada Favaron
body:
Area +31 is a visual essay that emulates the dynamics of amateur conspiracy theory video clips. It reproduces the typical visual grammar and audio patterns of the narratives found on streaming platforms all over the web: repetition, blurry focus, low resolution, voice-overs, shaky recordings, bold typography, brutal editing, zoom-ins, a dystopian atmosphere and neurotic music are several features of the vocabulary of conspiracy theorists.
In recent years, with the proliferation of fake news and algorithmic ‘linked stories’, the narratives of conspiracy theories have become an urgent topic for transdisciplinary research and discussion with a broader public. It has become more important than ever to make a distinction between true and false, credible and unconvincing. One could argue that these narratives can give a sense of community to those theorising and may even provide meaningful stories to society. These narratives inform our present and connect to our history in the future. They are an undesirable side effect of the large-scale globalisation and digitisation of society, and most of these speculations are relatively harmless. However, a few conspiracy theories do have tangible negative consequences in the world. These affect not only the public who believe in them but also the rest of the population, to whom they also appeal (and a valid example is the anti-vaccination movement).
Conspiracy theories have a subconscious appeal to people: they build on general distrust of authority; as human beings we all want answers that can make sense, through a convincing narrative, of obscure events and shifts in society. Exhibiting such a sceptical stance is not bad per se; raising doubts is comprehensible and a rather positive thing, but when driven by scepticism, we should allow proof and logic, or better yet, a scientific method, to temper our thinking.

The alleged aim of Area +31 is to speculate on the shift in the average height of the Dutch population and to convince the viewer that this change is highly conspicuous, anything but normal. From the script of the video: “How the Dutch became the world’s tallest people has been somewhat of a mystery. Two centuries ago they were renowned for being among the shortest, so… what happened? Scientists believe a number of factors are responsible for this striking increase, however this is just one possible answer given by so-called experts to prevent further investigations into the sudden shift. There may well be another theory that can bring us closer to the truth – another plausible answer that lies right under our noses every single day: food.

title: Windows
author: Iris Cuppen
body:
The initial aim of my research was to imagine a narrative system that could capture stills from a large media archive (and therefore from their original narratives/cultural frameworks) and re-connect them with other visual fragments in a new, digital and non-linear environment. While manually capturing snippets of the archive, I soon became interested in how the loop could be a useful tool in making sense of the many hours of material the Netherlands Institute of Sound and Vision hosts. As a result of the growing importance of the digital database as one of our most significant cultural structures, the many images on our screens slowly seem to transform from linearly constructed sequences into non-linear unstructured paradigms, from stories with an end and a beginning into never-ending fragments, from rich and sharp objects into poor and compressed file formats. When we speak of moving images in today’s digital realm, the loop seems to be an appropriate form to deal with this transformation, as it occupies a liminal space between story and instance. It is an in-between mode in which we can meditate on the many films of our past, without giving up on its movements, its livelihood.
The loop allows for an interesting kind of consumption, one that gives us the opportunity to reveal and repeat tiny gestures, unnoticed details and strange in-between moments, as it reduces the material to its essence again. The looping imagery is always in the ‘here and now’, and therefore it constantly seems to escape a unified and univocal meaning. To see a loop is to see it again. Every time we are confronted with it, we see it differently, opening up numerous possibilities for its future meaning in new contexts. While many of the moving images I have encountered in the archive would unfold in a linear, narrative system, the loop denies this form of storytelling by establishing constant reappearance. By constructing this mesmerising state, it touches upon a fundamental conception of time: the eternal.
At the same time, we can discover many traces of the material’s ephemerality in the archive, in the form of digital glitches or flickering celluloid. Our love for these traces could be seen as a form of identification, as a bodily relationship with the screen. This connection is not only evoked by the material’s physical decay, but also by the representation of a reality that once existed in front of the camera that, together with the actual material, slowly fades away. While writing Windows, I was constantly reminded of how much we love to encounter these fading realities through and on our rectangular screens. It was a confirmation of the idea that life suddenly becomes more interesting seen through a windowpane, especially over time. Watching our neighbours behind their glass windows, unaware of our voyeuristic act, is something many writers, filmmakers, and artists have been intrigued by. Today, however, this play of seen and being seen has become increasingly complex, as we can easily move through time and space on multiple levels. As we spend more and more of our time capturing and watching both our actual and our virtual realities on different screens in our streets, homes, and hands, the question of how the world is framed has therefore become even more important than what is framed. Windows uses both the loop and material from the archive as tools through which we can endlessly meditate on the glass openings we have carved out in our walls, vehicles, and screens and how these frames have changed the way we encounter our realities.
Sourse: https://openset-windows.tumblr.com/

title: Performative Gendered Gestures
author: Giulia Bardelli
body:
Performative Gendered Gestures stages the emphatic and performative side of children’s gestures. It is a fragmentary play that brings to the surface – and redesigns – hidden patterns lying behind the relationship between the body and the media. The play lays bare the unconscious performances that demand a critical reading of gender and the embodiment of sexuality.
The research project was spurred by the desire to research the way mass media positions itself in the discourse around the ‘gendered body’. Which kind of visual material does Dutch mass media deliberately decide to broadcast? Does the way media depicts our body twist the manner in which we perform ourselves? These leading queries can be approached with a personal focus – as a visual researcher – on the relationship between the body and mass media.
While diving into the Sound and Vision archive, gender started to increasingly become a performance, rather than a naturally shaped behaviour. A pool of recurring gestures came to the fore. Specific patterns emerged, composed by directives unconsciously absorbed from the predominant behavioural context. As Viktor Shklovsky suggested in Art as Technique in 1917, “[…] if we examine the general laws of perception, we see that as it becomes habitual, it also becomes automatic.” This process of automatisation can be analogous to the way people often automatise gestures and associate them to a specific gender – more or less unconsciously. But what happens if these patterns of gendered gestures are redesigned? What changes if they are fragmented and repeated?
Following this approach, the familiarity of the gestures started to vanish. The analysed actions turned into something unfamiliar. Their perception was not automatic anymore. As a result, repetition embodied a new (post)value. It became a de-automatising tool to slow down the process of reading of those patterns unconsciously perceived as mechanical by the gendered body.
All of a sudden, under a new revealing light, the meaning of the gestures changed. Among all the visual material previously selected, the performative and theatrical side of the gestures of children stood out strongly from the archive. In front of the camera, children behaved as if pushed by an unconscious need to over-perform their gender. As a result Performative Gendered Gestures began to take form. The children’s gendered bodies became the main characters. The gaze of the camera took on the role of director. Designing ceded its place to casting. Video-making became play-writing.
The final shape of the project can be seen as a metaphorical hybrid between a looped video and a theatrical play. The main patterns come to the surface through the four acts: allure, strength, sensuality, glance. Each one is composed by specific children’s gestures which repeat themselves, in order to emphasise the movement, slow down and de-automatise their perception. The overwhelming visual vocabulary of mass media is juxtaposed with a singular voice that opens each act: the sound of a child’s struggle to define her own identity. A detached voice takes on a counter part, staging the inner conflict between the predominant visual speech around gendered gestures and the individual. The final role is played by a familiar childhood sound, the music box, which has been repeated and slowed down as well. As a result, an unfamiliar background music cradles the rhythm played visually by the loops.

title: Kill our icons! (workshop by F. van der Stok)
author: Ada Favaron
body:
What if everything we are convinced of is a lie? If all we have been told by the media does not correspond to reality?
The material gathered for the workshop ‘Kill Our Icons!’ investigates the video material present in the archive and creates alternative interpretations of important dates in recent history: 9/11, the moon landing and the death of JFK, Elvis Presley and Lady Diana. These key moments of the last century are – either consciously or not – related to specific imagery: what would happen if such iconic images are replaced with different ones, not anymore familiar to us?
Together with each chosen frame related to the events, there is an article supporting (or analysing) the ‘conspiracy theory’ claimed.

“Something is wrong with this picture,” thought Nathan Lomba, S.E., P.E., of Eureka, California, as he watched televised replays of the Twin Tower collapses on September 11, 2001. As a licensed structural engineer trained in buildings’ responses to stress, Lomba saw more on the screen than did the average viewer. He tried to answer this perplexing question, “How did the structures collapse in near-symmetrical fashion when the damage was clearly not symmetrical?”
Lomba was hardly alone in his doubts and discomfort that day. Whether they publicly admit it or not, and whether they saw the events unfold “live” or watched endless television and internet reruns later, most building professionals — or individuals with any knowledge of building collapses — were surprised when the towers fell. 
(…)
Many structural engineers, like Lomba, find the unnatural symmetry of the fall of all three skyscrapers highly suspicious. The rapidity of collapse — eventually acknowledged by NIST as free-fall acceleration — also troubles them. Some note that the fires were weak, low-temperature, and short-lived. Others ask how the tilting upper section of the South Tower, WTC 2, “straightened” itself. Everywhere they look, pieces of the puzzle “don’t fit with what we’ve been told,” these engineers insist. 
AE911 – Architects and engineers for 9/11 truth (ae911truth.org)
James McDowell and AE911 Truth Staff
(06/02/2017)
http://www.ae911truth.org/news/199-news-media-events-60-structural-engineers.html
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2017/10/24/jfk-assassination-conspiracy-theories-the-grassy-knoll-umbrella-man-lbj-and-ted-cruzs-dad/?utm_term=.863a4668b54a

In early 1964 Stanley Kubrick had just finished his black satire Dr. Strangelove and was looking to do a science fiction film. While directing Dr. Strangelove, Kubrick had asked the US Air Force for permission to film one of their B-52 bombers for the movie. The Pentagon turned him down.
The movie, Dr. Strangelove, was about a flight squadron that had been ordered to fly to Russia and drop nuclear bombs on that country. The Pentagon read Kubrick’s script and rejected his request to actually film the inside, and outside, of a B-52. The reason for this rejection was that Kubrick’s film was clearly a satire on the military and US nuclear policy. The Pentagon did not want to assist Kubrick in this satirical undertaking.
Undaunted by the rejection, Kubrick used various special effects to create the B-52 in flight. When viewing Dr. Strangelove today, these special effects look quaint and old fashioned, but in 1963 they looked very good. It is possible that someone in
NASA saw what Kubrick had done in Dr. Strangelove and, admiring his artfulness, designated Kubrick as the person best qualified to direct the Apollo Moon landing. If he could do that well on a limited budget what could he do on an unlimited budget?
(…)
In the end, it looks like Stanley Kubrick faked the moon landings in return for two things. The first was a virtually unlimited budget to make his ultimate science fiction film: 2001: A Space Odyssey; and the second was that he would be able to make any film he wanted, with no oversight from anyone, for the rest of his life.
Reality Sandwich (realitysandwich.com) — How Stanley Kubrick Faked the Apollo Moon Landings
Jay Weidner
(??/??/2009)
http://realitysandwich.com/23226/kubrick_apollo/

A more widespread conspiracy theory is that the CIA — and even Lyndon B. Johnson — were nefariously involved.
Although experts have rejected it as “ridiculous” and “contrived,” the conspiracy theory was nonetheless central to Oliver Stone’s film. It has also been pushed by another Stone: Roger Stone, the political consultant and Trump confidant who
lobbied the president to release the final documents.
“I realize that delving into the world of assassination research and a belief in a conspiracy will lead some to brand me as an extremist or a nut, but the facts I have uncovered are so compelling that I must make the case that Lyndon Baines Johnson had John Fitzgerald Kennedy murdered in Dallas to become president himself and to avert the precipitous political and legal fall that was about to beset him,” Stone wrote in his 2013 book, written with Mike Colapietro, “The Man Who Killed Kennedy: The Case Against LBJ.”
(The book, which accuses Johnson of complicity in at least six other murders, also quotes Richard Nixon — Stone’s
former boss — as saying “Lyndon and I both wanted to be President, the difference was I wouldn’t kill for it.”)
The Washigton Post — JFK assassination conspiracy theories: the grassy knoll, Umbrella Man, LBJ and Ted Cruz’s dad
Michael E. Miller
(27/10/2017)
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2017/10/24/jfk-assassination-conspiracy-theories-the-grassy-knoll-umbrella-man-lbj-and-ted-cruzs-dad/?utm_term=.863a4668b54a

In the 40 years since he ‘died’, Elvis has been enjoying an active life.
He has been spotted working behind the checkout of a California grocery store and as a New York policeman.  
And appearing as an extra in an airport scene of the 1990 film Home Alone.
He visited Russia shortly after the Chernobyl disaster of 1986, but was back in the US to be spotted in 1988 in the quiet
village of Vicksburg, Michigan, by local woman Louise Welling, who saw him in the number two checkout queue of
Felpausch’s Supermarket, waiting to pay for an electrical fuse. While wearing a white jumpsuit.
The King also popped into the Burger King at 760 W. Michigan Ave in the nearby city of Kalamazoo. 
(…)
Last year, as a sprightly 81-year-old, Elvis was back at Graceland, working as a groundsman to ensure the estate’s 13.8 acres were kept in good order. Rumours he attended his own 82nd birthday proclamation ceremony at Graceland in
January were, however, swiftly debunked. 
Indipendent – Why are people so convinced Elvis is still alive? The bizarre world of ‘the King’s truth seekers’
Adam Lusher
(15/08/2017)
http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/elvis-presley-alive-sightings-seen-spotted-working-in-graceland-groundsman-82nd-birthday-proof-king-a7895261.html

This, according to Mohamed al-Fayed, was the reason for the killing. Diana had become pregnant with his son’s child, he said, and that idea was unpalatable to the British state.
Mr Fayed said that the royal family “could not accept that an Egyptian Muslim could eventually be the stepfather of the future King of England”. And so it plotted to kill her off.
Discussion of a potential pregnancy came up even before Diana died. During a holiday in France a few weeks before, some newspapers speculated that she might be pregnant, and that speculation was buoyed up by mysterious comments
Diana made about “a big surprise”.
Independent — Princess Diana conspiracy theories: Eight reasons people believe the crash in Paris wasn’t all it seems
Andrew Griffin

title: Nadia Christidi | I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings
abstract: Among Surinamese-origin communities from Biljmermeer, Amsterdam, to Queens, New York, bird-singing competitions are organized in public parks. Highly trained Picolets (Oryzoborus crassirostris) and Twa Twas (Oryzoborus angolensis), resident birds in Latin America, are made to face off in a bid to see which bird will sing most melodiously and for the longest. This tradition was carried […]
author: Nadia Christidi
body:
Among Surinamese-origin communities from Biljmermeer, Amsterdam, to Queens, New York, bird-singing competitions are organized in public parks. Highly trained Picolets (Oryzoborus crassirostris) and Twa Twas (Oryzoborus angolensis), resident birds in Latin America, are made to face off in a bid to see which bird will sing most melodiously and for the longest. This tradition was carried from Suriname, where official competitions have been held in the capital Paramaribo since the 1950s. Although the tradition’s origins there remain unknown, some speculate that it was brought over by an earlier wave of immigrants – indentured laborers conscripted by the Dutch from China, India, and Indonesia to replace slave labor post-abolition. The competitions, as such, attest to multiple transnational migrations – to the (voluntary and involuntary) movement of people, things, and practices. Since the early 1970s, the Surinamese community has had a significant presence in Bijlmermeer. 

In this workshop, the group engaged, both symbolically and literally, with bird singing competitions in Bijlmermeer. We used our engagement with this tradition as an entry point into exploring colonial histories, postcolonial experiences, and racial politics in the Netherlands; migration and community-building; culture in translation; and the circulation of accompanying things (ie. the economies of the bird trade, breeding, and betting). We complemented this emphasis on the ‘transnational’ with attention to the ‘translocal’ by grounding larger forces within their place-based experiences, meanings, and reformulation. Participants experimented with narrative and aesthetic forms to produce works that mobilize bird-singing competitions in Bijlmermeer to narrate the micro- and macro-political.
During the workshop one collaborator, an expert in Bird Singing contest, joined Hendry Bagwandin. With more then 50 years of experience, our guest of honour for this day is Hendry Bagwandin, a member of Ringmasters – a Surinamese Song Bird Community in Amsterdam South-East. RingMasters has existed for more than thirty years and is one of the largest Surinamese Songbird communities in the Netherlands together with Rotterdam and The Hague.
* “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings” is the title of a 1983 poem by Maya Angelou.

title: Pei-Ying Lin | Workshop Micro-performances / Macro-connections
abstract: This is a three days exploration of human as biological dynamic assembly – how we make connections with other living beings, and how human and all biological beings connect through the microscopic and macroscopic. How we live and perform together, how we migrate with each other, and how we transform each others. How do we share […]
author: Pei-Ying Lin
body:
This is a three days exploration of human as biological dynamic assembly – how we make connections with other living beings, and how human and all biological beings connect through the microscopic and macroscopic. How we live and perform together, how we migrate with each other, and how we transform each others. 
How do we share our experiences and how do we make connections with other people through the encounter of other species with our inner side of the body? The workshop will be looking at these relationships through food relating with the participants and Bijlmer area, from the scale of earth to the scale of microscopic. By getting to know the people and, restaurants, and markets with food in Bijlmer area to map out the activities of microbes and ‘biological activities’ within the community. And more particularly, fermentation, migration, and microbes migration. These materials will become the ‘ingredients’ we construct our new biological possibilities. Through developing different sensorial ways of observing to create an expanded performance that doesn’t only happen at human scale but also inside the human body and hopefully across communities. In short and simple words: we will be creating a performance with the microbes telling the story of human and microbes migration while exploring the possibilities of deepening the relationship and reflecting what we really are.
During the workshop two collaborators (experts in Nigerian and Surinam cuisines) will join:
– Justina Uka born in the Eastern part of Nigeria, a mother of 6 children grew up with  Nigerian fermented products. She lives more than 40 years in the Netherlands and never ceased to cook with these products on a daily basis.  She will explain what fermented products goes well together and what combinations are served in the Nigerian cuisine.
– Mavis Hofwijk & Candice Hofwijk. Surinamese Buffet Catering was founded in 1985 by Mavis Hofwijk and arises from her love for authentic Surinamese cuisine. Nowadays, Mavis leads this thriving company together with her daughter Candice Hofwijk, in Amsterdam Zuidoost. The dishes she prepares in her kitchen are a reflection of the kitchen that has developed in the Surinamese melting pot over the centuries.

title: Negotiating Difference in the City of Tomorrow
author: Dash N' Dem
Irina Shapiro

title: DashN’Dem | MASS VOICE’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’
abstract: All: (in line) WORKERS’ THEATRE! WORKERS’ THEATRE! WORKERS’ THEATRE! 1st: The theatre of workers like yourselves 2nd: Who play in every town and country 3rd: To workers like yourselves All: WORKERS’ THEATRE! WORKERS’ THEATRE!       WORKERS’ THEATRE! 4th: We show the life of working men and women 5th: Their hardship and their hunger 6th: Their […]
author: Dash N' Dem
body:
All:  (in line) WORKERS’ THEATRE! WORKERS’ THEATRE! 
WORKERS’ THEATRE! 
1st:  The theatre of workers like yourselves
2nd:  Who play in every town and country 
3rd:  To workers like yourselves
All:  WORKERS’ THEATRE! WORKERS’ THEATRE! 
       WORKERS’ THEATRE! 
4th:  We show the life of working men and women
5th:  Their hardship and their hunger
6th:  Their struggle to exist 
 
Extract from Their Theatre and Ours (1932)
Agitprop theatre groups took theatre to working class people. They were mobile groups that played in a variety of locations including factories, warehouses, pubs, the streets and on demonstration lines. Rejecting bourgeois notions of theatre, agitprop actors simplified the content and put more emphasis on the message, often relying on their physical bodies and voice.
Mass Recitation was agitprop theatre striped to it’s barest theatricality, a dramatic form of choral speaking in which actors chanted in verse to the accompaniment of choreographed movements and gestures as an enactment of revolutionary dynamism. It was used as a powerful vehicle to address the audience and call for social action. 
“The mass recitation was perhaps the most innovative agitprop form, and the one that most clearly modelled the aesthetics of revolutionary modernism. It was one of those rare forms discovered in praxis. It combines the cadence and oratory of nineteenth-century recitations with staccato rhythms, segues and transitions of radio. It is telegraphic in its terseness, and semaphoric in its use of signifying bodies. At its most effective it was drilled and choreographic. As a polyphonic chorus, it could achieve a percussive musicality familiar today in hip hop, and it may be that the first New York mass recitations were influenced by African-American oral poetry.”
– Alan Filewood

We will update this historical form of agitprop with workshops participants and residents of Biljimeer, producing a collective call for social action today. A mass rap responding to the vibrant rhythms of the Bilmer, a dynamic multicultural community with music and dance from Kaseko to hip-hop.
Responding to historic scripts, the form and structure of mass recitations will be used to confront issues and explore the communities hopes and fears. For example, how dramatic emphasis was created by dividing questions and answers between the group and individual performers. Contrasting private doubts with the strength and unity of the chorus, as a powerful metaphor for the collective power of the group.
 
MASS RECITATION DESIGN PROCESS

STORYLINE: Exploring Bijlmer, investigating issues, events, characters and actions 
DIALOGUE: Collective writing, arranging the content and starting to develop prose.  
ARRANGEMENT OF VOICES: Playfully exploring patterns, rhythm and pitch to produce meaning and emotional effect. Who chants what part of the dialogue and how? 
MOVEMENT: Sourcing and choreographing the movements and gestures that accompany the vocal arrangement. 
MUSIC: Responding to the vibrant rhythms of the Bilmer, Kaseko, and hip-hop. 

 
During the workshop, Mizztamizzo will join as collaborators.
Rapper Mitchell ‘Mizztamizzo’ from Ommeren is an MC / producer born and raised in the Bijlmer. Besides being a solo artist, he is also part of the formation of Free Quincy together with rapper Ell-I-Dee and producers de Raven Bros.

title: Heather Barnett  | City as Superorganism
abstract: Artist and researcher Heather Barnett will lead two days of fieldwork exploring the area of Bijlmer as a superorganism, a system of dynamic interconnected networks. Shifting perspectives across species and scales, participants will observe, interrogate and interact with their urban surroundings through a series of individual and collective experiments. From slime mould cells to urban […]
author: Heather Barnett
body:
Artist and researcher Heather Barnett will lead two days of fieldwork exploring the area of Bijlmer as a superorganism, a system of dynamic interconnected networks. Shifting perspectives across species and scales, participants will observe, interrogate and interact with their urban surroundings through a series of individual and collective experiments. From slime mould cells to urban infrastructure, ideas of fluidity will be explored through a nonhuman lens, looking at interconnections, information flow and feedback loops. From simple elements, complex behaviours may emerge…
Day One: Perspective Shifts; Maps and Models.
Day Two: Stigmergic Traces; Sensory Explorations.
 


 
City as Superorganism, Workshop led by Heather Barnett, Summer School 2018
City as Superorganism, Workshop led by Heather Barnett, Summer School 2018
City as Superorganism, Workshop led by Heather Barnett, Summer School 2018
City as Superorganism, Workshop led by Heather Barnett, Summer School 2018

title: Rik Smit | Platforms of Memory. Social Media and Digital Memory Work
abstract: Social media platforms have become important technologies of memory. In specific ways, they re-present our collective and personal past and help to transfer specific representations of it into the future. This talk explores how this ‘digital memory work’ is distributed among old and new media actors, both human and ‘nonhuman’. The talk revolves around three […]
author: Rik Smit
body: Social media platforms have become important technologies of memory. In specific ways, they re-present our collective and personal past and help to transfer specific representations of it into the future. This talk explores how this ‘digital memory work’ is distributed among old and new media actors, both human and ‘nonhuman’. The talk revolves around three case studies. The first case study focuses on YouTube and witness footage from the ongoing conflict in Syria. It asks how videos made by witnesses in the aftermath of the 2013 chemical weapons attack in Ghouta are curated, ‘remixed’, and re-presented. The second case study presents a typology of the memory work done on Justice for Mike Brown, a Facebook page set up after the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson. Lastly, I present a case study on the memory work on Wikipedia in the context of the wiki on the downing of flight MH17.

title: Robert M Ochshorn | Faster and Less Accurate. Post-Spreadsheet Digital Archives
abstract: Without diminishing the historic importance of the spreadsheet, the time has come to think beyond its rigid cells. The spreadsheet carries with it the promise of extreme visibility, columnar uniformity, and explicit computational operations. With present quantities of media, however, it is no longer possible to see everything filed away properly and acted upon with […]
author: Robert M Ochshorn
body: Without diminishing the historic importance of the spreadsheet, the time has come to think beyond its rigid cells. The spreadsheet carries with it the promise of extreme visibility, columnar uniformity, and explicit computational operations. With present quantities of media, however, it is no longer possible to see everything filed away properly and acted upon with simple rules. What imperfect forms, compressions, and associations can we design into a next generation of digital archives?
